What we can do for others is a good feeling in moderation if we can provide it without being self harmful about it
People like me with autism and hyper empathy tend to overdo it, but enjoying being kind or giving to others should ideally never be tied to self worth. It should just make you feel good

Advice on how to prove your worth to yourself is a harder answer, unfortunately, since it requires a personalized approach
But the 1st step is to always know you have inherent worth and right to be in spaces and on this planet. And that you have a right to your physical and emotional needs being met

People pleasing won’t increase self worth, it’ll just breed resentment when others don’t appreciate it in the way you need
Often that resentment is aimed at yourself, convinced you’re doing something wrong
But truth is, you already have inherent worth, you’re instead seeking validation to “prove it”

Obviously my experience is the outlier, but y’all all seemed familiar with how infamous chows can be, so I figured I’d share my experience with the best version of a chow an the worst nightmare version, since it’s relevant to both nurture and the “holy crap don’t adopt aggressive dogs” topic

My parents never forgave themselves and never did rescuing ever again. That experience has stayed with me my entire life and it’s why I get so uncomfortable by people A) adopting aggressive animals on purpose and B) adopted any dog on a whim with little care or preparation

One day, he saw my tottling along in the yard (I was 5/6), and he not only broke through the metal leash but also somehow broke through the metal fence in a wild impulse to hunt me. I was throw around like a rag doll, mauled and hospitalized for months, and I’m lucky to be alive.
As he became an adult, my parents started keeping him leashed and fenced off farrrr away from me, because they were worried about how his mental health wasn’t improving.

But they started noticing as he got older that the chronic inbreeding (he was a rare white chow achieved via severe inbreeding but it didn’t impact his physical health as much according to vets) deeply negatively impacted how his brain worked.

My parents did everything right from the beginning and even involved experts, including chow experts, to make sure the rescue went well. And at first, he didn’t show any abnormal behavior for a chow at that age.

The one chow was your standard reddish color and the kindest dog I’ll ever know. Sweet as can be, naturally house trained himself, friendly to kids and strangers (but was still more loyal to specific people), etc.
The other chow? Horrible with abnormally severe aggression and mental issues
